nodes.bodyText: out of scope: Surely, we need a builder for JdbcTableHandle
nodes.diffHunk:

-                        handle.getLimit()),
+                        handle.getLimit(),

nodes.bodyText:
Builder for JdbcTableHandle would free us from modifying call sites, but it would also make it very error-prone.
Having to actually modify all the call sites forces me to go thru them and update them (add a condition, pass-thru some field or do nothing).
I am strongly against adding a builder for this class.

-                        handle.getLimit()),

nodes.bodyText:
Builders can be used full to simulate named arguments. When a methods has too many arguments or arguments with similar types, that can be error prone (e.g, if there are multiple boolean arguments).
You can avoid missing callsites by making the builder validate that all required values have been set. This will catch any errors when the tests run (so, obviously, it relies on having good coverage). It's not as good as a compile-time failure, but without named argument support in Java there's not much else we can do.

nodes.bodyText:
Sure, but it's very very tempting to have a JdbcTableHandle.builderFrom(JdbcTableHandle handle) method, which totally undermines any safety which we really need here.
For this reason, I am convinced not having a builder class is less error-prone that having one for handling JdbcTableHandle transformations.

nodes.bodyText: This could be handled differently in different sql engines
We can revisit as needed, wdyt?
it would be nice to have unit tests for this class that would test SQL string generation.
We do not have any such tests yet. For example, we have TestJdbcQueryBuilder which is an integration test against H2.
added
AvgFloatingPointAggregateFunctionRule?

I decided on "implement .." nomenclature. Considered also "rewrite".
What is the advantage of the proposed name?

Implement is an empty word here, does not add any new value.
There is a convention of naming implementations in a <flavour><type> way. That way it is easy to understand what it is. We follow this with optimizer rules. Changing this here is unintuitive.
shoudn't this be a default behaviour?

it is. However, Phoenix extends JdbcMetadata, so inherits JdbcMetadata behavior, but it does not work for Phoenix case, as it does something special in io.prestosql.plugin.phoenix.PhoenixClient#buildSql.

Also we need some smoke tests for aggregation push down added to base jdbc smoke test that could be reused by other connectors. Such test should handle aggregration rewrites that are implemented in base-jdbc module.
There are no rewrites handlded on base-jdbc level. There are rewrite rules provided by base-jdbc, but it's up to specific connector to mix & match them (and test them).
put table name to separate line
don't you need to assert here what was pushed down?
i assert that "everything" got pushdown and "yet" results are correct.
remove?
Done
This should be a TODO. There's no reason why it shouldn't be possible to apply filters after a aggregations (i.e., a HAVING clause, or a WHERE clause in an enclosing query)
added TODO
Why did this switch from StringBuilder to string concatenation?
StringBuilder use here was unnecessary and made the code harder to read and work with.
